      @keyframes w3m-shake {
        0% {
          transform: scale(1) rotate(0deg);
        }
        20% {
          transform: scale(1) rotate(-1deg);
        }
        40% {
          transform: scale(1) rotate(1.5deg);
        }
        60% {
          transform: scale(1) rotate(-1.5deg);
        }
        80% {
          transform: scale(1) rotate(1deg);
        }
        100% {
          transform: scale(1) rotate(0deg);
        }
      }
      @keyframes w3m-iframe-fade-out {
        0% {
          opacity: 1;
        }
        100% {
          opacity: 0;
        }
      }
      @keyframes w3m-iframe-zoom-in {
        0% {
          transform: translateY(50px);
          opacity: 0;
        }
        100% {
          transform: translateY(0px);
          opacity: 1;
        }
      }
      @keyframes w3m-iframe-zoom-in-mobile {
        0% {
          transform: scale(0.95);
          opacity: 0;
        }
        100% {
          transform: scale(1);
          opacity: 1;
        }
      }

Key operators include the entities managing the underlying \\\"payment rails\\\"—the infrastructure enabling fund movement. Prominent examples in the US include the \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"ACH\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\" (Automated Clearing House), newer real-time systems like \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"FedNow\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\" (Federal Reserve) and \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"RTP\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\" (The Clearing House), and the ubiquitous card networks (Visa, Mastercard, American Express, Discover). \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Globally, systems like \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"SWIFT\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\" facilitate interbank messaging for cross-border transfers, while regional networks like \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"SEPA\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\" in Europe or \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"UPI\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\" in India handle domestic or regional flows. Payment processors act as intermediaries, facilitating transaction authorization and settlement between merchants, consumers, and financial institutions. The primary payment types flowing through these rails include traditional methods like credit transfers, direct debits, checks, and cash deposits.\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"tag\":\"h2\",\"type\":\"heading\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Opportunities for Stablecoins in Today’s Payments Industry\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textFormat\":1},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"The global payments industry processes trillions of dollars annually, but remains filled with inefficiencies. High fees, slow transactions, and complex systems create opportunities for innovation—especially for solutions like stablecoins. Stablecoins directly address the core weaknesses inherent in traditional systems:\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"tag\":\"h3\",\"type\":\"heading\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Lower Costs \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textFormat\":1},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Traditional payment methods, particularly those crossing borders, remain prohibitively expensive. Retail cross-border payments can consume up to 6% of the transaction value, with remittances being notoriously costly – averaging around 6.6% globally for sending a modest sum like $200. \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"B2B payment systems often involve settlement delays ranging from hours to several business days, especially for international transactions, which can take 2-5 days or longer. stablecoin landscape is diverse, with different types categorized primarily by the mechanism used to maintain their price stability, or \\\"peg.\\\" Understanding these distinctions is crucial, as the underlying structure significantly impacts a stablecoin's risk profile, transparency, regulatory standing, and suitability for various use cases. \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"tag\":\"h3\",\"type\":\"heading\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Fiat-collateralized stablecoins\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textFormat\":1},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"These stablecoins are the most prevalent type. They maintain their peg by holding reserves of a specific fiat currency (or highly liquid, safe equivalents like short-term government treasuries) equal to or exceeding the value of the stablecoins in circulation. \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Examples include USD Coin (USDC), PayPal USD (PYUSD), and Tether (USDT). Their dominance suggests a market preference, particularly among institutional users and those seeking lower risk, for models that closely mirror traditional financial structures and offer transparency through audited reserves.\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"tag\":\"h3\",\"type\":\"heading\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Commodity-collateralized stablecoins\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textFormat\":1},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"These stablecoins are backed by reserves of physical commodities, most commonly precious metals like gold. The value of the stablecoin is pegged to the market price of the underlying commodity. \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Examples include Paxos Gold (PAXG) and Tether Gold (XAUt).  \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"tag\":\"h3\",\"type\":\"heading\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Crypto-collateralized stablecoins\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textFormat\":1},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"These maintain their peg by holding reserves of other cryptocurrencies. Because the collateral itself can be volatile, these systems typically require over-collateralization – meaning the value of the crypto held in reserve significantly exceeds the value of the stablecoins issued (e.g., 150% or more). Smart contracts often manage the collateralization levels and liquidation processes automatically. \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"id\":\"68250fc8543463539af09d1a\",\"type\":\"link\",\"fields\":{\"url\":\"https://www.helius.dev/blog/solana-permissioned-blockchains\",\"newTab\":false,\"linkType\":\"custom\"},\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":3,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"permissioned the characteristics of the stablecoin solution: the degree of decentralization, accessibility, governance structure, inherent compliance capabilities, transaction costs, speed, etc. \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":8},{\"tag\":\"h3\",\"type\":\"heading\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Permissionless Blockchains\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textFormat\":1},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Permissionless blockchains, such as Solana Mainnet or Ethereum Mainnet, offer open access: anyone can build applications, issue tokens (subject to platform rules), and participate in the network. Fintechs often opt for these because they can build and iterate quickly, and target broad markets without needing approval from a central authority. \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Solana, in particular, achieves very high transaction throughput (surpassing 4,000 transactions per second in production today, with a theoretical capacity of 65,000), settlement in around 400 milliseconds, and extremely low transaction fees. \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"These attributes have made Solana an increasingly popular choice for deploying stablecoins and building high-frequency payment applications, decentralized finance (DeFi) protocols, and consumer-facing services. \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Ethereum Mainnet has historically faced significant scalability challenges. Its popularity often leads to network congestion, resulting in high transaction fees (\\\"gas fees\\\") and slower confirmation times. \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Rollups, Ethereum Layer 2 Solutions, are designed to process transactions on a separate layer and periodically submit compressed transaction data and state proofs back to the Ethereum Mainnet. \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"tag\":\"h3\",\"type\":\"heading\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Permissioned Blockchains\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textFormat\":1},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Permissioned blockchains operate with restricted access, requiring authorization for participation, transaction validation, and often governance. This controlled environment provides several advantages, particularly for regulated entities like financial institutions seeking to use blockchain, but are concerned with security, identity, and regulation. \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Key benefits include enhanced security through known validators, the ability to implement robust, network-level compliance features (like KYC/AML checks), greater control over data privacy, and tailored governance structures. \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"id\":\"68250fc8543463539af09d1b\",\"type\":\"link\",\"fields\":{\"url\":\"https://www.sphere.net/\",\"newTab\":true,\"linkType\":\"custom\"},\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":3,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Spherenet\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":8,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textFormat\":8},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\" Initially at slot n (transaction processed), there’s some risk the transaction could be “skipped” or forked out. With optimistic confirmation (confirmed), the inclusion likelihood sharply rises as validators vote. After enough consecutive forks are built upon it (finalized), the probability of reversal reaches effectively zero. This demonstrates the decreasing risk of rollback as commitment level increases.\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":2,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":2},{\"tag\":\"h2\",\"type\":\"heading\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"How does Solana determine commitment levels?\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textFormat\":1},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Understanding how Solana’s consensus works “under the hood” can clarify why these commitment levels exist:\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"tag\":\"h3\",\"type\":\"heading\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Proof of History (PoH) and Block Production\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textFormat\":1},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Solana’s leaders produce blocks in rapid succession (one leader per slot, slots ~400ms). When a leader produces a block with your transaction, that block is immediately propagated but not yet confirmed — corresponding to the \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Processed\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\" stage.\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":8},{\"tag\":\"h3\",\"type\":\"heading\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Voting (Tower BFT)\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textFormat\":1},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Solana uses a BFT consensus algorithm called \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"id\":\"6824bc2f3a64ae36345825cc\",\"type\":\"link\",\"fields\":{\"url\":\"https://www.helius.dev/blog/consensus-on-solana#tower-bft-solanas-consensus-mechanism\",\"newTab\":false,\"linkType\":\"custom\"},\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":3,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Tower BFT\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":8,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textFormat\":8},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\". Validators (each controlling some stake) vote on blocks they believe should become the next part of the ledger. Votes are themselves Solana transactions, and they include a concept of \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"lockout\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\". Every time a validator votes on a block at slot \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"N\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":2,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\", it incurs a lockout such that if it later votes on a conflicting fork, it might lose the ability to vote for some time. \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":8},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"These lockouts double exponentially with each successive vote on the same fork (1, 2, 4, 8... slots of lockout) and cap at 32 votes. If a validator has voted 32 times in a row on a fork (meaning the block from 32 slots ago is still part of the heaviest fork), that block is at \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"max lockout\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\". This mechanism incentivizes validators to stick with the majority fork and finalize blocks.\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"tag\":\"h3\",\"type\":\"heading\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Confirmation (Optimistic Confirmation)\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textFormat\":1},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"When a block is produced, validators broadcast votes for it. As soon as a supermajority (≥66%) of stake has voted on a block, Solana nodes consider that block \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"optimistically confirmed\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\". This is the \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Confirmed\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\" commitment level. It happens quickly, often within one or two slots after the block, because votes propagate via gossip. \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Importantly, Solana’s implementation doesn’t require waiting for the block to become rooted in the ledger; it trusts the supermajority vote as an optimistic signal that this block will be finalized eventually (barring \u003c33% of stakes misbehaving). \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"This is why it’s called \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"optimistic confirmation\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":2,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\": under normal Byzantine fault assumptions (at most 1/3 dishonest), a supermajority vote means the block will not be overturned. If a fork was to override it, \u003e33% of validators would have to vote for an alternate chain, which breaks the assumptions.\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"tag\":\"h3\",\"type\":\"heading\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Finalization (Rooting a Block)\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textFormat\":1},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"As new blocks continue to be produced and voted on, each confirmed block moves deeper in the fork. Once a block has accumulated votes in 32 consecutive slots after it, it reaches the maximum lockout. At this point, the network \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"roots\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\" that block, marking it as finalized and irreversible. Finalization means the block is at least 31 blocks behind the head and was never abandoned in favor of another fork. All nodes now consider this block part of the immutable history (ledger state up to that slot is frozen). \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"In effect, the \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Finalized\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\" commitment corresponds to “block has ≥32 confirmations” in a \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"id\":\"6824bc2f3a64ae36345825cd\",\"type\":\"link\",\"fields\":{\"url\":\"https://www.helius.dev/blog/proof-of-history-proof-of-stake-proof-of-work-explained#what-is-proof-of-work\",\"newTab\":false,\"linkType\":\"custom\"},\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":3,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"PoW chain\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":8,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textFormat\":8},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\" analogy, but Solana achieves this via time-locked votes rather than proof-of-work confirmations. The 32-slot rule is a consequence of Tower BFT’s design (lockouts doubling until 2^32) and provides a mathematical guarantee of finality under the 1/3 fault tolerance assumption.\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"tag\":\"h3\",\"type\":\"heading\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Fork Choice \u0026 Rollback\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textFormat\":1},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Solana’s consensus continuously evaluates forks. Validators use a heaviest-fork selection algorithm (based on stake voting weight) to decide which fork to build on. If a block is only processed by a subset of validators and fails to get votes, another fork can override it. This is why a \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Processed\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\" transaction can be dropped. \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Once a block is confirmed by 2/3, an alternative fork would have to have more than 1/3 of stake behind it to win, which is very unlikely and would imply malicious behavior. \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"After finalization, a fork that rewinds that block is essentially impossible without a catastrophic consensus failure. Even if the network halted or was attacked, reverting finalized slots would require coordination outside the protocol rules.\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"To summarize the mechanics: \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Processed\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\" = block produced (PoH) but not widely voted yet; \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Confirmed\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\" = cluster votes (Tower BFT) reached supermajority on the block (optimistic consensus); \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Finalized\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\" = block has persisted as the chain “root” after many more votes (absolute consensus finality). Solana’s design ensures that confirmed blocks become finalized after a short delay, providing fast confirmation and eventual absolute finality.\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"tag\":\"h2\",\"type\":\"heading\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Developer Use Cases for Each Commitment Level\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textFormat\":1},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Choosing the appropriate commitment level is crucial when building on Solana. Different applications have different requirements for speed vs. certainty. \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Here are typical use cases and best practices for each level:\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"tag\":\"h3\",\"type\":\"heading\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Use Processed for Immediate Feedback and Non-Critical Ops\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textFormat\":1},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Developers might use the \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Processed\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\" commitment in scenarios where speed is paramount and some risk of rollback is acceptable. For example, during development and testing, you may want instantaneous confirmation that a transaction \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"was received\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":2,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\" by a validator. \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"UI applications (like wallets or games) could optimistically show a transaction as soon as it’s processed to improve user experience (e.g., show a “pending” state). \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"However, because processed transactions aren’t guaranteed to stick, this level is \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"not recommended for production-critical flows\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\". If used, it should be for low-value or non-critical transactions where a potential rollback would not cause serious issues.\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"tag\":\"h3\",\"type\":\"heading\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Use Confirmed for Most Transactions\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textFormat\":1},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"The \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Confirmed\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\" level is generally the recommended default for many use cases on Solana. stablecoin landscape is diverse, with different types categorized primarily by the mechanism used to maintain their price stability, or \\\"peg.\\\" Understanding these distinctions is crucial, as the cases. \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"tag\":\"h3\",\"type\":\"heading\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Fiat-collateralized stablecoins are the most prevalent type. They maintain their peg by holding reserves of a specific fiat currency (or highly liquid, safe equivalents like short-term government treasuries) equal to or exceeding the value of the stablecoins in circulation. \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Examples include USD Coin (USDC), PayPal USD (PYUSD), and Tether (USDT). Their dominance suggests a market preference, particularly among institutional users and those seeking lower risk, for models that closely mirror traditional financial structures and offer transparency through audited reserves.\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"tag\":\"h3\",\"type\":\"heading\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Commodity-collateralized stablecoins\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textFormat\":1},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"These stablecoins are backed by reserves of physical commodities, most commonly precious metals like gold. The value of the stablecoin is pegged to the market price of the underlying commodity. \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Examples include Paxos Gold (PAXG) and Tether Gold (XAUt).  \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"tag\":\"h3\",\"type\":\"heading\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Crypto-collateralized stablecoins\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textFormat\":1},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"These maintain their peg by holding reserves of other cryptocurrencies. Because the collateral itself can be volatile, these systems typically require over-collateralization – meaning the value of the crypto held in reserve significantly exceeds the value of the stablecoins issued (e.g., 150% or more). Smart contracts often manage the collateralization levels and liquidation processes automatically. Fintechs often opt for these because they can build and iterate quickly, and target broad markets without needing approval from a central authority. \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Solana, in particular, achieves very high transaction throughput (surpassing 4,000 transactions per second in production today, with a theoretical capacity of 65,000), settlement in around 400 milliseconds, and extremely low transaction fees. \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"These attributes have made Solana an increasingly popular choice for deploying stablecoins and building high-frequency payment applications, decentralized finance (DeFi) protocols, and consumer-facing services. \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Ethereum Mainnet has historically faced significant scalability challenges. Its popularity often leads to network congestion, resulting in high transaction fees (\\\"gas fees\\\") and slower confirmation times. \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Rollups, Ethereum Layer 2 Solutions, are designed to process transactions on a separate layer and periodically submit compressed transaction data and state proofs back to the Ethereum Mainnet. \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"tag\":\"h3\",\"type\":\"heading\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Permissioned Blockchains\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textFormat\":1},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Permissioned blockchains operate with restricted access, requiring authorization for participation, transaction validation, and often governance. transaction. When you query a Solana RPC node for a transaction’s status or account data (e.g., getTransaction), you can specify a commitment level to indicate how finalized you want the data to be. Solana uses this commitment level to let clients balance \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"latency vs. certainty\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\": lower commitment gives quicker feedback, while higher commitment levels give developers stronger assurances that the state won’t revert.\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Solana defines three primary commitment levels (in descending order of finality):\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"tag\":\"h3\",\"type\":\"heading\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Finalized\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textFormat\":1},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"The highest level of certainty, indicating the block has been confirmed by a super-majority of stake (≥66 %), and at least 31 further confirmed blocks have been built on top of it, giving the slot the maximum 32-vote lock-out. A finalized transaction is effectively irreversible.\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"tag\":\"h3\",\"type\":\"heading\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Confirmed\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textFormat\":1},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"An intermediate level where the block has been voted on by a supermajority of stake (≥66%), but not yet finalized by a more extended period of continued voting that makes it harder to reverse. This is often called \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"optimistic confirmation\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\", providing a strong assurance the transaction is on the “main fork,” or canonical chain.\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"tag\":\"h3\",\"type\":\"heading\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Processed\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textFormat\":1},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Processed means the transaction was just processed by a leader and included in the most recent block that the node knows about. However, that block may not yet have any cluster-wide votes. The transaction \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"could\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":2,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\" still be dropped if that block doesn’t end up in the majority fork.\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"These levels represent stages in a transaction’s lifecycle. \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"A freshly submitted transaction will move from Processed → Confirmed → Finalized as more of the network observes and votes on the block containing it, and subsequent blocks are built atop that block. Higher commitment implies more nodes have agreed on the transaction’s inclusion, reducing the risk of a fork or rollback. \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Let’s explore each level in detail.\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"tag\":\"h2\",\"type\":\"heading\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Processed Commitment Level\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textFormat\":1},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"A transaction is \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Processed\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\" as soon as a validator node (i.e., the current leader) includes it in a block. This is the earliest acknowledgment: the transaction has been received and incorporated into the ledger state As soon as a supermajority (≥66%) of stake has voted on a block, Solana nodes consider that block \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"optimistically confirmed\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\". This is the \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Confirmed\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\" commitment level. It happens quickly, often within one or two slots after the block, because votes propagate via gossip. \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Importantly, Solana’s implementation doesn’t require waiting for the block to become rooted in the ledger; it trusts the supermajority vote as an optimistic signal that this block will be finalized eventually (barring \u003c33% of stakes misbehaving). \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"This is why it’s called \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"optimistic confirmation\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":2,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\": under normal Byzantine fault assumptions (at most 1/3 dishonest), a supermajority vote means the block will not be overturned. If a fork was to override it, \u003e33% of validators would have to vote for an alternate chain, which breaks the assumptions.\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"tag\":\"h3\",\"type\":\"heading\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Finalization (Rooting a Block)\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textFormat\":1},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"As new blocks continue to be produced and voted on, each confirmed block moves deeper in the fork. Once a block has accumulated votes in 32 consecutive slots after it, it reaches the maximum lockout. At this point, the network \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"roots\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\" that block, marking it as finalized and irreversible. Finalization means the block is at least 31 blocks behind the head and was never abandoned in favor of another fork. All nodes now consider this block part of the immutable history (ledger state up to that slot is frozen). \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"In effect, the \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Finalized\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\" commitment corresponds to “block has ≥32 confirmations” in a \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"id\":\"6824bc2f3a64ae36345825cd\",\"type\":\"link\",\"fields\":{\"url\":\"https://www.helius.dev/blog/proof-of-history-proof-of-stake-proof-of-work-explained#what-is-proof-of-work\",\"newTab\":false,\"linkType\":\"custom\"},\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":3,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"PoW chain\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":8,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textFormat\":8},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\" analogy, but Solana achieves this via time-locked votes rather than proof-of-work confirmations. The 32-slot rule is a consequence of Tower BFT’s design (lockouts doubling until 2^32) and provides a mathematical guarantee of finality under the 1/3 fault tolerance assumption.\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"tag\":\"h3\",\"type\":\"heading\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Fork Choice \u0026 Rollback\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textFormat\":1},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Solana’s consensus continuously evaluates forks. Validators use a heaviest-fork selection algorithm (based on stake voting weight) to decide which fork to build on. If a block is only processed by a subset of validators and fails to get votes, another fork can override it. This is why a \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Processed\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\" transaction can be dropped. \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Once a block is confirmed by 2/3, an alternative fork would have to have more than 1/3 of stake behind it to win, which is very unlikely and would imply malicious behavior. \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"After finalization, a fork that rewinds that block is essentially impossible without a catastrophic consensus failure. Even if the network halted or was attacked, reverting finalized slots would require coordination outside the protocol rules.\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"To summarize the mechanics: \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Processed\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\" = block produced (PoH) but not widely voted yet; \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Confirmed\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\" = cluster votes (Tower BFT) reached supermajority on the block (optimistic consensus); \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Finalized\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\" = block has persisted as the chain “root” after many more votes (absolute consensus finality). Solana’s design ensures that confirmed blocks become finalized after a short delay, providing fast confirmation and eventual absolute finality.\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"tag\":\"h2\",\"type\":\"heading\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Developer Use Cases for Each Commitment Level\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textFormat\":1},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Choosing the appropriate commitment level is crucial when building on Solana. Different applications have different requirements for speed vs. certainty. \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Here are typical use cases and best practices for each level:\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"tag\":\"h3\",\"type\":\"heading\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Use Processed for Immediate Feedback and Non-Critical Ops\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textFormat\":1},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Developers might use the \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Processed\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\" commitment in scenarios where speed is paramount and some risk of rollback is acceptable. For example, during development and testing, you may want instantaneous confirmation that a transaction \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"was received\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":2,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\" by a validator. \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"UI applications (like wallets or games) could optimistically show a transaction as soon as it’s processed to improve user experience (e.g., show a “pending” state). \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"However, because processed transactions aren’t guaranteed to stick, this level is \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"not recommended for production-critical flows\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\". If used, it should be for low-value or non-critical transactions where a potential rollback would not cause serious issues.\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"tag\":\"h3\",\"type\":\"heading\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Use Confirmed for Most Transactions\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textFormat\":1},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"The \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Confirmed\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\" level is generally the recommended default for many use cases on Solana. It offers a strong assurance of success with minimal latency impact. \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"For instance, a DeFi application making a token swap or a user transferring funds will usually rely on confirmed status: once the transaction is confirmed, the app can treat it as completed in the normal case. This level significantly reduces the chance of a transaction being dropped compared to \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Processed\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\". Best practice is to use a commitment level of \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Confirmed \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"especially when querying recent blockhashes and sending transactions, as it provides a better balance between latency and safety.\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"tag\":\"h3\",\"type\":\"heading\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Use Finalized for High-Value and Critical Transactions\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textFormat\":1},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"When absolute certainty is required, such as high-value asset movements, cross-chain bridges, or exchange deposit confirmations, developers should use the \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"Finalized\",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":1,\"version\":1},{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\" commitment level. This is common for scenarios where even a tiny risk of rollback is unacceptable. \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"For transactions have lower reliability. \",\"type\":\"text\",\"style\":\"\",\"detail\":0,\"format\":0,\"version\":1}],\"direction\":\"ltr\",\"textStyle\":\"\",\"textFormat\":0},{\"type\":\"paragraph\",\"format\":\"\",\"indent\":0,\"version\":1,\"children\":[{\"mode\":\"normal\",\"text\":\"As If an application waits for finalization, it must account for that extra time.
